gloss-3-1-3.note: Otfrid wrote this gloss AFTER the second glossator had added the reference sign and the marginal gloss concerning 'gloriam'. Sometimes, however (see below), the second glossator clearly wrote after Otfrid. Thus, the two writers added their glosses and worked with this manuscript almost at the same time

gloss-5-0-1.note: The second glossator wrote 'Vox est' above the lemma, then stopped and re-started writing his gloss below the lemma linking it to line II 5, 2

Duobus modis minima pars dicitur·|ABBREVIATION VEL|  quia totius sy〈llabae - C. G.〉 uel dict〈ionis - C. G.〉 minima p〈ars - C. G.〉 est uel quia [. . . . .]|ABBREVIATION VEL|  dictio diu〈idi - C. G.〉 potest lite〈ra - C. G.〉 autem diuid〈i non - C. G.〉 potest·

|REFERENCE SIGN S| [a - expunction by Otfrid] l[e - expunction by Otfrid]〈i〉tera· a lego et itere |ABBREVIATION VEL|  lituris 〈dilenne - added by Otfrid〉 liniuntur enim cum cera tabulę. fricando enim deletur tabula

gloss-6-13-1.note: for the OHG word dilenne see Rudolf Schützeichel, Althochdeutsches Wörterbuch. Siebente durchgesehene und verbesserte Auflage Berlin/Boston 2012, p. 312, s.v. ardīlēn =to delete. Dilenne is an infinitive in the dative case translating the instrumental ablativelituris of the gloss. We have here a gloss of a gloss. I am very thankful to Prof. Wolfgang Haubrichs for his expertise and precious help.

gloss-21-22-1.note: See: 'clavus, m.', in: Mittellateinisches Wörterbuch accessed 16.02.2024. It seems to me that Otfrid declined here the word 'clavus/clabus, -i' (i.e. nail, second Latin declension) according to the fourth declension. 'Clabu vel clauu' seems to be an ablativus instrumentalis that Otfrid wrote as a gloss on the verb 'scalpo', in order to explain what one scratches with.

gloss-21-22-2.note: This OHG gloss was first edited by Hans Butzmann,Althochdeutsche Priscian-Glossen aus Weissenburg, PBB. 86/3 (Halle 1964), pp. 388-402, at p. 391, no. 4.

analysis: definition given by an entire sentence

gloss-24-9-3.note: This OHG gloss was first edited by Hans Butzmann,Althochdeutsche Priscian-Glossen aus Weissenburg, PBB. 86/3 (Halle 1964), pp. 388-402, at p. 392, no. 5. It recurs in MS München, BSB, clm 280a, f. 6r. - The gloss 'frequenter spuo' occurs also in MS Köln 200, f. 6v and MS München, BSB, clm 18375, f. 11r. It seems that Otfrid firstly wrote 'spuo uel rachison' and that he later added 'frequenter' before 'spuo' and 'uel parum poto' after 'rachison'.

gloss-27-5-2.note: MS Köln 200, f. 7r conveys both explanations 'palus inferni' and 'fluuius infernalis'; MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 11v has 'fluuius infernalis'; MS BSB Clm 280a f. 6r has 'flumen infernalis'.

gloss-27-7-1.note: MS Köln 200, f. 7r reads 'gigas nomen proprium'.

analysis: glosses elucidating the main text with red marginal title

gloss-27-14-1.note: MMS BSB Clm 280a f. 6v contains a similar gloss: 'proprium nomen serui'.

reading.text: |REFERENCE SIGN INVERTED CRYPHIA| proprium |ABBREVIATION VEL|  qui de datia est

gloss-27-15-1.note: MS Köln 200, f. 7v contains a similar gloss: 'nomen uiri vel gentis siue distinctus'. Davus is a sclave in Terence's comedy 'Andria'. Otfrid did not have this information, whereas the glossator of gloss-27-14-1 did.

gloss-27-15-2.note: MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 12r contains the gloss: 'parefredus'. See entry 'paraveredus' in: A. Blaise,Lexicon latinitatis medii aevi.

gloss-27-15-3.note: MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 12r and Clm 280a, f. 6v contain the similar gloss: 'velox nuntius'.

reading.text: Tamen habemus ·u· correptum & productum sicut eoles ·oy

analysis: glosses elucidating the main text with a title

reading.text: De semiuocalibus· Sed primum de ·l· incipit
analysis: glosses elucidating the main text with red marginal title

reading.text: |REFERENCE SIGN DISTIGME|  idem est quod maxilla· sed maxilla diminutiuum a mala

analysis: glosses elucidating the main text with red marginal title

gloss-29-15-2.note: MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 12v and Clm 280a, f. 7r contain the similar gloss: 'id est obscure nomen pro aduerbio'.

gloss-29-15-3.note: MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 12v and Clm 280a, f. 7r contain the similar gloss: 'id est aperte nomen pro aduerbio'.

|REFERENCE SIGN DICOLON| ex ambabus partibus cesus
|REFERENCE SIGN INVERTED N|  ex omni parte quero

gloss-29-21-1.note: MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 12v and Clm 280a, f. 7r contain the same gloss.

gloss-29-21-3.note: For the rare word 'circumesus' see: Du Cange, Glossarium mediae et infimae latinitatis, s.v. 'ambesus'.

gloss-29-22-2.note: Otfrid wrote first the gloss 'circumagens'. Later he added the further explanation 'circuitus' introducing it with a 'uel'.

analysis: glosses elucidating the main text with red marginal title

gloss-30-19-1.note: MS BSB Clm 18375, f. 13r contains the same gloss.

gloss-30-22-4.note: This OHG gloss was first edited by Hans Butzmann,Althochdeutsche Priscian-Glossen aus Weissenburg, PBB. 86/3 (Halle 1964), pp. 388-402, at p. 392, no. 8.

gloss-30-22-5.note: This OHG gloss was first edited by Hans Butzmann,Althochdeutsche Priscian-Glossen aus Weissenburg, PBB. 86/3 (Halle 1964), pp. 388-402, at p. 392, no. 9. Otfrid added this gloss to the previous OHG gloss at a later stage, using a different ink.

gloss-33-21-1.note: This multilingual gloss was first edited by Hans Butzmann,Althochdeutsche Priscian-Glossen aus Weissenburg, PBB. 86/3 (Halle 1964), pp. 388-402, at p. 392, no. 10.

gloss-33-21-2.note: The otherwise unattested word 'defenio' is probably an erroneous transcription of 'deficio', which appears as a gloss to 'exoleo' in MS Köln 200, f. 8v.

reading.text: |REFERENCE SIGN VIRGA DOT| extraneus|REFERENCE SIGN VIRGA DOT|

gloss-33-22-3.note: Either Otfrid himself or another writer deleted this gloss by expunction. The explanation 'extra spem' occurs in MS Köln 200, f. 8v, next to the more frequently occurring 'sine spe'.

reading.text: subtinnio & succumbo non mutauerunt ·b· in ·s· quia ex sub· praepositione & tinnio & cumbo uerbis composita sunt

gloss-34-12-2.note: A similar explanation occurs in MS Köln 200, f. 9r.

gloss-34-16-4.note: With this gloss Otfrid added the lemma 'effluo', which had been skipped by the copyist of Priscian's text, and provided its etymology.
